abase.definition: cause to feel shame; hurt the pride of

examples.example: And yet when he says, “I am from outer space,” some of you actually shut your eyes, abase your intellects, and believe!
“Should I abase myself? Rub ashes in my hair? Tear my clothes?”
Rather they are measurements of the amount of time that stick-figure heads bob up and down or left and right to fawn over the person who is president or to abase his flaws.
Cojocaru especially was a force of nature, the moment where she fell on her knees before Kobborg had a reckless, raw abandon that made the gesture anything but self abasing.
Much of the classical music industry has since abased itself at Mäkelä’s feet.
Yet when she isn’t mooning or abasing herself to win the attention of a handsome fellow intern, she shows off a preternatural self-possession, the girl with all the answers.
Before the company, she reiterated the ballet’s gesture of amorous veneration, making her arms a halo that she drew over his head, shoulders, torso, and legs, abasing herself at his feet.

But one German theologian has recently proposed explanatory footnotes to turn the most problematic passages — the black children abasing themselves before Pippi, for example — into educational opportunities.

abase.blurb: To *abase* something or someone is to humiliate them — no, more than just humiliate them. If you *abase* another person you are bringing them low, humbling them in a mean, *base* manner. Not nice at all.
abase.background: *Abase* means to bring someone down, often either in their job or their self-esteem. The early Latin *bassus*, which meant "thick, low," evolved into the Old French *abaissier*, meaning "to make lower in value or status." The important clue to the word is "base." Consider that the base of anything is the bottom, and you get an idea as to the meaning of the word *abase*, which means to make someone feel low.

abate.definition: become less in amount or intensity

examples.example: Already the sudden storm is passing, and its fierceness is abating; crowds are scattering homeward, and the sky is beginning to redden over the Yorkshire wolds.

abate.blurb: Something that *abates* becomes fewer or less intense. Your enthusiasm for skiing might *abate* after falling off a ski lift and getting a mouthful of snow.
abate.background: *Abate* comes from the Old French verb *abattre*, "to beat down," and means to reduce or become less intense or numerous. As an intransitive verb, it is often used with something physically, emotionally, or figuratively violent, as in "the flood of fan mail began to *abate*." Using it transitively, if you take measures to abate pollution or noise, you reduce them. Pronounce *abate* with the stress on the second syllable (uh-BATE).

abhorrent.blurb: Many people find cruelty toward animals *abhorrent*, that is, they think it's detestable, obscene, repugnant, repulsive, and offensive to the mind. In other words, they really, really don't like it.
abhorrent.background: When you think of *abhorrent*, think of *horror*, as in something so vile and loathsome that you can only react to it in horror. In fact, the word *abhorrent* in Latin means “to recoil (back away) in horror.” Note that the ending is spelled *-ent* with an *e*, not an *a*. Maybe the *a* found *abhorrent* so abhorrent that it didn’t want to appear in it a second time.

examples.example: She was one of the few things abhorrent to him that he could touch and therefore hurt.

adorn.definition: make more attractive by adding ornament, colour, etc.
adorn.blurb: To *adorn* is to dress something up by decorating it. You might *adorn* your poncho with fringe or your poodle's dog collar with rhinestones.

affectation.definition: a deliberate pretense or exaggerated display

apothecary.definition: a retail shop where medicine and other articles are sold

artifice.definition: a deceptive maneuver (especially to avoid capture)

aspersions.definition: an abusive attack on a person's character or good name

austere.definition: of a stern or strict bearing or demeanor; forbidding in aspect

bamboozle.definition: to deceive or get the better of (someone) by trickery, flattery, or the like

bazaar.definition: a street of small shops, especially in the Middle East

bedeviled.definition: be confusing or perplexing to; cause to be unable to think clearly

bedlam.definition: a state of extreme confusion and disorder

benediction.definition: a ceremonial prayer invoking divine protection

bombastic.definition: ostentatiously lofty in style; inflated; pretentious

boon.definition: something to be thankful for; blessing; benefit

cajole.definition: influence or urge by gentle urging, caressing, or flattering

cerebral.definition: involving intelligence rather than emotions or instinct

chicanery.definition: the use of tricks to deceive someone (usually to extract money from them)

circumlocution.definition: a roundabout or indirect way of speaking; the use of more words than necessary to express an idea

clandestine.definition: conducted with or marked by hidden aims or methods

cleft.definition: a space or opening made by cleavage; a split

conflagration.definition: a very intense and uncontrolled fire

contagion.definition: any disease easily transmitted by contact

contravene.definition: go against, as of rules and laws

curios.definition: any unusual article, object of art, etc., valued as a curiosity

curtail.definition: to cut short; cut off a part of; abridge; reduce; diminish

deliriously.definition: marked by uncontrolled excitement or emotion

denouement.definition: the outcome of a complex sequence of events

dichotomy.definition: being twofold; a classification into two opposed parts or subclasses

duplicitous.definition: marked by deliberate deceptiveness, especially by pretending one set of feelings and acting under the influence of another

eclectic.definition: combining or composed of elements drawn from a variety of sources

elysian.definition: being of such surpassing excellence as to suggest inspiration by the gods

epicurean.definition: displaying luxury and furnishing gratification to the senses

erstwhile.definition: belonging to some prior time; former

eschew.definition: avoid and stay away from deliberately; stay clear of

extant.definition: still in existence; not extinct or destroyed or lost

felicitous.definition: exhibiting an agreeably appropriate manner or style

flummoxed.definition: be a mystery or bewildering to

foibles.definition: a minor weakness or peculiarity in someone's character

folly.definition: a foolish action, practice, idea, etc.; absurdity

foolhardy.definition: marked by defiant disregard for danger or consequences

gallivant.definition: wander aimlessly in search of pleasure

godspeed.definition: good fortune; success (used as a wish to a person starting on a journey, a new venture, etc.)

gregarious.definition: fond of the company of others; sociable

examples.example: Those were the salad days, the halcyon years!

harangue.definition: deliver a harangue to; address forcefully

howling.definition: extraordinarily good or great ; used especially as intensifiers

ignoble.definition: completely lacking nobility in character or quality or purpose

examples.example: The eldest also intimated that the mother was a mild anal retentive personality.
examples.source: How the García Girls Lost Their Accents

examples.example: I have already intimated that my condition was much worse, during the first six months of my stay at Mr. Covey’s, than in the last six.
examples.source: Narrative of the Life of Frederick Douglass

examples.example: Diana intimated that this would be a different parting from any they had ever yet known.
When the cheering had died down, Napoleon, who had remained on his feet, intimated that he too had a few words to say.
But surviving testimony intimates that it was well on its way.

jonesing.definition: to have a craving for something or someone (sometimes followed by for or out)

judicious.definition: marked by the exercise of good judgment or common sense in practical matters

juxtaposition.definition: the act of positioning close together (or side by side)

kibitz.definition: to give uninvited or unwanted advice

labyrinthian.definition: resembling a maze in form or complexity
labyrinthian.blurb: *Labyrinthine* is a good word to describe a place that feels like an enormous maze. A new student at a huge, sprawling high school is likely to find the building *labyrinthine* as she wanders the halls looking for her math class.

lamentations.definition: a cry of sorrow and grief

languish.definition: experience prolonged suffering in an unpleasant situation or place

lexicon.definition: the vocabulary of a particular language, field, social class, person, etc.

malaise.definition: a vague sense of unease or dissatisfaction

merriment.definition: activities that are enjoyable or amusing

metastasize.definition: to transform, especially into a dangerous form

milieu.definition: surroundings, especially of a social or cultural nature

navigable.definition: capable of being steered or guided, as a ship, aircraft, or missile

obsequious.definition: attentive in an ingratiating or servile manner

paramour.definition: an illicit lover, especially of a married person

persnickety.definition: characterized by excessive precision and attention to trivial details

podunk.definition: any small and insignificant or inaccessible town or village

pontificating.definition: talk in a dogmatic and pompous manner

portends.definition: to indicate in advance; to foreshadow or presage, as an omen does

precipice.definition: the brink of a dangerous or potentially disastrous situation

predilection.definition: a predisposition in favor of something

quagmire.definition: a situation from which escape is very difficult

quixotic.definition: not sensible about practical matters; idealistic and unrealistic

quotidian.definition: found in the ordinary course of events

rattletrap.definition: a shaky, rattling object, as a rickety vehicle.

raucous.definition: disturbing the public peace; loud and rough

razzmatazz.definition: any exciting and complex play intended to confuse (dazzle) the opponent

regale.definition: occupy in an agreeable, entertaining or pleasant fashion

relinquish.definition: to renounce or surrender (a possession, right, etc.)

repose.definition: freedom from activity (work or strain or responsibility)

reverence.definition: a feeling of profound respect for someone or something

sacrosanct.definition: treated as if holy and kept free from violation or criticism

scruples.definition: moral or ethical considerations or standards that act as a restraining force or inhibit certain actions

skullduggery.definition: verbal misrepresentation intended to take advantage of you in some way

slight.definition: to treat (someone) with indifference; ignore, especially pointedly or contemptuously; snub

examples.example: The assassin might have bothered to care about the slight if she had any interest in courtiers.

spendthrift.definition: a person who spends possessions or money extravagantly or wastefully; prodigal

striations.definition: a stripe or stripes of contrasting color

sundries.definition: miscellaneous objects too numerous or too small to be specified

talisman.definition: a trinket or piece of jewelry usually hung about the neck and thought to be a magical protection against evil or disease

tommyrot.definition: pretentious or silly talk or writing

travesty.definition: a distorted, debased, or absurd imitation of something

trepidations.definition: a feeling of alarm or dread

voluptuous.definition: displaying luxury and furnishing gratification to the senses

vouchsafe.definition: to grant or give, as by favor, graciousness, or condescension
